senses.de: Related to the subject that is being discussed or considered
senses.ex: He asked a lot of questions that were not pertinent to the topic.

Tips.title: Context Clarity
Tips.description: Use 'pertinent' when something has a clear link to the main subject being discussed.
Tips.example: Only bring up pertinent facts during the meeting.

Tips.title: Avoid Off-topic
Tips.description: 'Pertinent' signals that the information is not off-topic or irrelevant.
Tips.example: Her comments were not pertinent and distracted from the main issue.

Tips.title: Academic Tone
Tips.description: 'Pertinent' often appears in formal or academic contexts, signaling professionalism.
Tips.example: The researcher included only the most pertinent data in his study.

senses.de: Appropriate or suitable in a particular situation
senses.ex: This training is pertinent for your job.

Tips.title: Situation Specific
Tips.description: Use 'pertinent' to describe something well-suited for the specific circumstances or needs.
Tips.example: The guide provided us with pertinent advice for navigating the city.

Tips.title: Timeliness
Tips.description: 'Pertinent' also implies that something is not just suitable, but also timely and current.
Tips.example: The briefing will cover the most pertinent developments in the case.

senses.de: Directly connected with and important to something
senses.ex: The politician failed to address the pertinent issues during the campaign.

Tips.title: High Relevance
Tips.description: When something is 'pertinent', it holds significant weight or importance to the issue at hand.
Tips.example: During the trial, only pertinent evidence was considered.

Tips.title: Problem-Solving
Tips.description: In problem-solving, focus on the pertinent factors that directly influence outcomes.
Tips.example: To identify a solution, we must evaluate all the pertinent factors affecting sales.

Applicable.wordDefinition:
Applicable means that something is relevant or appropriate to a particular situation or subject. For example, if you are talking about a job application, the skills and experience listed on your resume should be applicable to the job you are applying for.

So, while both words suggest a connection or relevance to a particular situation or topic, applicable is more general and can be used in a wider range of circumstances, while pertinent is more specific and is typically used when referring to something that is essential to a particular topic.

Appropriate.wordDefinition:
Appropriate means suitable or fitting for a particular purpose or situation.

It describes something that is proper and in line with expectations or accepted norms. For example, wearing formal attire to a job interview is appropriate.

To summarize, appropriate refers to something that is suitable and in accordance with expectations, while pertinent refers to something that is directly related to a specific topic or subject.

Fit.wordDefinition:
Fit means something that matches or is suitable for a particular purpose or situation. For example, if you buy new shoes, you want to make sure they fit properly so you can walk comfortably.

Fit refers to something that is suitable or matches, while pertinent refers to something that is relevant or applicable.

Germane.wordDefinition:
Both germane and pertinent are adjectives that refer to relevance or applicability in relation to a particular situation or topic.

However, germane tends to specifically refer to the direct and immediate connection between two things, while pertinent can refer to something that is indirectly related but still relevant or has a bearing on the matter at hand.

For example, if you are having a discussion about a specific car model and someone brings up a completely unrelated topic such as the weather, you could say that their comment is not germane to the conversation because it is not directly related to the car.

Germane describes something that is directly relevant and necessary to the discussion, while pertinent describes something that is more loosely related but still relevant or useful.

Material.wordDefinition:
Material refers to something that is relevant and important to a particular topic or subject. For example, in a court case, the evidence presented should be material to the case.

Material refers to something that is relevant to a particular topic or subject, while pertinent refers to something that is directly related and important to the matter at hand.

Relevant.wordDefinition:
The words pertinent and relevant mean similar things, but there are some differences.

Relevant means that something is connected to the topic at hand or has some bearing on it. It might not be as specifically related as something that is pertinent, but it's still important.

For example, if you're writing an essay about the history of basketball, a relevant fact might be that other popular American sports like baseball and American football were also developing around the same time.

So, in short, pertinent is more specific and narrowly focused, while relevant is broader and more general. Both can be useful depending on the context of what you're trying to say or write.

Significant.wordDefinition:
Significant refers to something that has a substantial or meaningful impact or importance.

However, a significant fact would be the decline in fish populations due to changes in temperature and water acidity.

Pertinent refers to something that is relevant or directly related, while significant refers to something that has a substantial or meaningful impact.

Suitable.wordDefinition:
Suitable means appropriate or fitting for a particular purpose or situation. It implies that something is a good match or suitable for a specific need.

For example, if you are going on a hike, wearing comfortable shoes and warm clothing is suitable because they are appropriate for the activity.

Pertinent is used when something is directly related to a topic or situation, while suitable is used when something is a good match or appropriate for a particular purpose or need.
